jyoshu

Civil War, D.C.-style
 "It's a war the media can't win, and shouldn't wage.
 
 The intense grilling that White House reporters inflicted on presidential spokesman Scott McClellan Monday over whether political guru Karl Rove leaked the name of a CIA operative was no ordinary give-and-take. It was a hostile hectoring that revealed much of the mainstream press for what it has become: the opposition party.
 
 Forget fairness, or even the pretense of it. With one of its own locked up - Judith Miller of The New York Times - much of the Beltway gang has declared war on the White House."
 
 http://www.nydailynews.com/news/col/story/327547p-279954c.html

Ghost

Can you explain to me how homosexuality is being "forced on you"?

 
 I wasn't speaking from my own point of view, rather from the people who are dead set against it. They feel that activist judges are trying to make something socially acceptable which many people do not. Regardless of your feelings, many of the courts which have made pro-gay marriage rulings in the past year or so have not been actual legal rulings. That's why many of them have been revoked since then. But also, I think they feel offended by the fact that there are so many shows on tv now which paint homosexuality as something totally acceptable and fit for public consumption. Many people in this nation are not comfortable with that.
 
 Personally, I don't like homosexuality. But I do see gays as people, deserving of the same respect as a human being that is entitled to anyone else. I'm no gay-basher, and I judge people based on who they are and not their sexual preference. I don't support gay marriage, but I support something like civil unions, which carry many of the same rights and responsibilities. It's a difficult subject, because simultaneously you have to protect the rights of the minority, while following the will of the majority.

Do you actually understand what you're attempting to argue?

 Everyone has the right to marry anyone else of the opposite sex. Per the legal (both statutory and common law) definition of marriage.
 
Nobody cares why any two people marry each other. What's at stake are the legal rights of a spouse as they pertain to issues like medical insurance, taxes, etc.

 There's no discrimination present as to the rights of a spouse as to medical insurance, taxes, etc.

The gay movement faces segregated schools, segregated restrooms, being forced to sit in the back of busses, being called names just for walking down the street, restricted housing availability, receiving lower paying jobs, and exclusion from major colleges and professions all because of who they are.
 
 Oh wait, no.

 People are being denied housing for being gay.

 Gay people are excluded from the military profession.
 
 But you are right, they don't have to sit at the back of the bus.
 
 Equal rights are equal rights. Any time basic rights are denied anyone, it diminishes us all. And that is the most important parallel to the civil rights movement.
biccat

Gays get called names, beaten up, and sometimes killed for being gay.

 Hate crimes still exist against whites, blacks, jews, etc, etc. You can't identify someone as gay seeing them walking down the street, they don't get called names in public.
 
 Racism was indiscriminate, anti-homosexuality is not.
 
 
People are being denied housing for being gay.

 Not on an institutional basis, as was the case in racial discrimination. The Supreme Court upheld housing restrictions on deeds for a long time ("this house shall not be sold to anyone not of the white race"), then reversed couse and said no discriminary clauses in deeds.
 
 I can discriminate to my hearts content when I want to sell my house. I just can't enforce it on my successors in interest. This is the only type of discrimination gays face, same as anyone else.
 
 Oh yeah, and there are gay-only communities, so the 'discrimination' apparantly goes both ways.
 
 
People are being fired for being gay.

 Well, if you're openly gay, and your employer finds out about it, yes, this does happen. And it probably isn't right. Maybe homosexuality should be a protected class?
 
 Strangely enough, my employer has no idea as to my sexual preferences and background, so I don't see why this should be an issue.
 
 
Gay people are excluded from the military profession.

 No, openly gay people are excluded. Again, it's not right, and you have the ultra-progressive Clinton to thank for that one.
 
 
Equal rights are equal rights. Any time basic rights are denied anyone, it diminishes us all.

 Waxy

 
 The biggest difference is that "prejudice" over the gay issue is really because they believe the behavior is immoral. I've never known a religious person who opposed a person having a particular nature. But they do oppose som behaviors; homosexual sex is one of them. I think it is safe to say that most preachers who speak out against gays are speaking out on the behavior issue, not on them as a person.
 
 Racial prejudice is much different. It is not about the behavior, but about the person and qualities about that person that aren't liked (skin color for instance).
Waxy

The biggest difference is that "prejudice" over the gay issue is really because they believe the behavior is immoral. I've never known a religious person who opposed a person having a particular nature. But they do oppose som behaviors; homosexual sex is one of them. I think it is safe to say that most preachers who speak out against gays are speaking out on the behavior issue, not on them as a person.
 
 Racial prejudice is much different. It is not about the behavior, but about the person and qualities about that person that aren't liked (skin color for instance).

 
 Firstly, as Sinjin has pointed out, if you honestly believe that segregation and racial prejudice were not seen as moral issues, you are woefully ignorant on the subject.
 
 Further to that, I think your assertion that most "religious people" don't oppose a particular nature, only a behaviour, is pure hogwash.
 
 That said, in your mind, as in that of most religious people, there's no objection to people being homosexual, until they have sex, then you object strongly, because it's a moral issue. How can you justify that in reality? 
 
 You claim to have no problem with homosexuals that don't have sex. 
 
 How is that different than me saying I have no problem with blacks - until they listen to rap music, speak in ebonics, and kick my butt at basketball, then I can't tolerate them, it's a moral issue. 
 
 Is that a moral issue I have with blacks? If not, why? The Bible? I'm sure I could find more than a few verses that could be "interpreted" to support my assertion.
 
 Is that position superior to saying that I don't like blacks regardless of their actions simply because they're black? According to your line of reasoning re homosexuality, it is. IMHO, that's an absurd assertion.
 
 You stated that predjudice is about "the person and qualities about that person that aren't liked (skin color for instance)". How is that any different than the quality of being attracted to the same sex or having limp wrists? IF homosexuality has a genetic component (I believe it does, I know you don't, but let's not get into that debate here), then how is it any different than skin colour. In reality, even skin colour can be changed, just ask Michael Jackson. 
 
 While I agree that gay rights movement and the civil rights movement are a few orders of magnitude off in terms of impact on those affected, I think to deny the comparison of the two as being valid is ridiculous.
 
 Waxy
